entry.title: strawberry pie (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that strawberry pie (example pictured) is one of the "red foods" traditionally served at Juneteenth celebrations?

entry.title: T. E. Lawrence (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that T. E. Lawrence travelled 1,000 miles (1,600 km) on foot alone during a three-month tour of crusader castles while writing his thesis about the Crusades and European military architecture?

entry.title: Kopka River (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that although the provincial park surrounding the Kopka River had not been thoroughly investigated, the potential for archaeological sites was considered to be high?

entry.title: Yuri Shcherbinin (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that despite his distinguished family history, musicologist Yuri Shcherbinin told friends that "what matters most is what you are, not who your ancestors were"?

entry.title: Nihon Shōgakkō fire (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the serial arsonist who started the fatal Nihon Shōgakkō fire confessed to starting at least 25 other California fires in the early 1920s?

entry.title: Wilhelm Werner (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Wilhelm Werner fled to Brazil to avoid prosecution for the 1917 murders of the crew of the SS Torrington but returned to Germany and became an SS officer on Heinrich Himmler's staff?

entry.title: TriGem (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in 1981, TriGem introduced the first microcomputer built in South Korea?

entry.title: Canticle II: Abraham and Isaac (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in Canticle II: Abraham and Isaac, Benjamin Britten assigned the tenor of Peter Pears to Abraham and the alto of Kathleen Ferrier to Isaac, with both singing in homophony as the voice of God?
